Shape: A small songbird with a short, pointy crest, a short, stubby bill, a moderately long tail, and rounded wings.
Compared Size: Larger than a Ruby-crowned Kinglet, smaller than a Western Bluebird.

description: An ashy gray bird with a boldly striped black-on-white face made up of a sweeping black line on the crest, a line through the eye and bordering the cheek, and black patches on the nape and throat.

Moves rapidly through middle levels of taller trees, investigating leaves and needles for hidden insects, often hanging upside-down to probe or reach. Usually found in small foraging groups that include family members as well as other woodland bird specie.
Resident in oak, pine-oak, and riparian woodlands at higher elevations (typically above 5,000 feet).
